Journalists will be silenced.  Government and law enforcement records will be wiped.  Witnesses will disappear.  For all practical purposes you will simply cease to exist.  
Acquiring a new identity will reset your notoriety rating.
It would be wise to check in at the reception as one of the first things you do at the Casino. That will give you a base.
The security is very tight in high profile casinos, that's the reason the staff carry keycards which provide access to the floors they work upon only.
As requested, we have left an Agency Pickup in your hotel room, #701.
In a casino like this one, strict security rules are to be followed in case of a fire. Therefore, easily accessible fire alarms are located on the top floors.
It's always important to find good vantage points. Room balconies may provide this, because they give a good overview of the premises.
These high roller places always have VIP areas. To access those you need some sort of pass. Checking the areas out might be a good idea, since important people tend to gather here.
To prevent cheating at the tables the casino has blocked all cellphone signals inside the building
We are suspecting that the materials used in the trade are carried around in a suitcase. We suspect that it will look rather ordinary to not catch too much attention.
If you climb up through the maintenance hatch of an elevator, you will be able to strangle unsuspecting people standing underneath, by taking out the fiber wire and pressing the action button .
With a handgun equipped, you can silently approach a person from behind, and use the person as a human shield by pressing the action button.
You can strike a person by pressing the fire button when standing in front of them. They are either stunned or knocked unconscious.
When enemies get close and dirty, and pull their weapon, you can disarm them by pressing the fire button. This will let them have a taste of their own medicine.
If a person is standing next to a railing or atop a flight of stairs, you can push them from behind by pressing the fire button

Disposing of bodies is important if you don’t want to blow your cover or raise unneeded alarms. Use crates, freezers and boxes to hide bodies in, or dispose them over railings. To do so drag them to the nearby container or rail and press the action button to dispose of the body.
If you act suspicious, civilians will report your actions to the nearest guards.
You can walk around with your fiber wire out, but if you tighten it by pressing the fire button, people will panic.
Guards and civilians will attempt to wake up unconscious persons. Therefore it’s a good idea to hide unconscious bodies if you want to prevent this from happening.
By throwing items you can distract people. You throw items by pressing the throw button.

Although disguises will allow you to access restricted areas, you have to be careful, because some people will see through your disguise and blow your cover. Keep a keen eye on the visual indicator on your HUD at the lower left corner.

The map is very useful in planning your approach. You can use it to locate your targets, track guards and find points of interest.  Remember though, that the difficulty setting of your choosing, will affect how much information is disclosed at the map!

During a mission, an exclamation mark will appear under the compass at the top of the screen from time to time. This means that new relevant info has been added to your mission briefing. Read it because it will give you clues on critical mission events.

At any point in the game, you can access the mission briefing by pressing the mission briefing button. Here you can replay the briefing, read information that has taken place during the mission, and read extra intelligence.

Police were shocked but not entirely surprised by yesterday's bloodshed at the "abandoned"  Southland Amusement Park.  Most law enforcement officials conceded that they'd been aware of illegal activity on the grounds for several years.

"We suspected something going on," says Chief of Police Kevin Armstrong, "but since it was private property -- the Swing King lived out there, you know -- and we weren't receiving any complaints, there wasn't much we could do."
And now it appears they won't have to.  Yesterday's violence apparently cleaned the park out in a way law enforcement officials never could or would have attempted.  It was a story told by body-bags.

"Whoever did this," the chief observes, "and we're thinking it was some kind of rival gang, or some very unhappy business associate--whoever did this is still guilty of multiple murders, and we're obviously going to pursue them.  But I'd be lying if I said we weren't a little relieved.  Makes our job a whole lot easier when the bad guys take each other down for us."

Attorneys for Joseph "Swing King" Clarence's estate have said that the defunct park will be auctioned off to cover outstanding legal expenses their client, who was killed in the violence, had built up in recent years.
Clarence is survived by his wife, who was reportedly working with attorneys to file for divorce at the time of his death.
Five hours short of their scheduled execution, two death row inmates escaped custody yesterday during a spectacular attack on the prison transport taking them to their place of execution.
The transport was struck in transit by an armoured truck. A dramatic and bloody firefight followed the collision. The escaped convicts have been identified as Adam Marcus and "Mr. Little".

Dozens were killed in the episode, described by one witness as "brutal open warfare." The FBI described the operation as "staggering" in its precision. Marcus is a notorious mercenary, rumoured to be a member of "The 7", but police dismiss rumours of that organization's involvement.
Mr. Little, on the other hand, is reportedly an unstable and heavily-medicated psychopath. Both are convicted murderers, armed and dangerous.
Residents of the Buena Vista neighborhood held a public meeting last night to express their frustration with the city council's recent approval of plans for a new mall on Birch Boulevard.

Residents fear the mall, financed by Natas Construction Corporation, will be a public eyesore, will increase local traffic congestion, and will bring Buena Vista neighborhood property values down significantly.

"We've already got the Silver Springs Mini-Mall, the Jefferson Boulevard Shopping Center, and the Red Oak Mall," angry resident Mike Taylor explained at the meeting.  "All of our consumer needs are being met.  There's no reason to build another mall within twenty miles of Buena Vista."
"The city council was bribed!" screamed one angry resident from the audience, "Off with their heads!"  Though extreme, the sentiment did not seem unpopular.  [cont'd, p. 2]
Kids' Lemonade Stand Condemned and Demolished

Hannah, Sophie, and Molli Cousins, aged 8, 6, and 2, respectively, stood on the corner of Maple and Broad Streets yesterday afternoon and watched with tears in their eyes as their hand-made lemonade stand was demolished by municipal workers.
The three sisters had been operating their lemonade stand for several days, charging a quarter per glass of their homemade lemonade.

But their stand apparently siphoned some business from nearby convenience-store owner Bob Klontz, who contacted local authorities and insisted the girls' lemonade stand be held to the same standards as any other local business.
Not surprisingly, the girls' amateur workmanship and substandard hygiene failed to pass inspection.  The stand was condemned, and two workers were sent out to dismantle it.
Mr. Klontz looked on with approval and even applauded as the workers wrenched the wobbly stand apart.  A bulldozer idled nearby.  [Cont'd, p. 4]

The biotech boom of the 1990s is widely credited with having created more than 40,000 jobs in the southland region.  Following Monday's announcement that Human Genome Solutions (HGS) will be closing down its local operations, however, the number of southland residents employed by the biotech sector may dip below 5000 for the first time since 1992.
The phenomenon isn't just local.  Biotech firms across the country are closing their domestic operations and relocating overseas, to countries whose political climate aren't as inhibiting.

"The anti-cloning movement is understandable as an instinctive if misinformed rebellion against the commoditization of human life," says industry observer Gail H. Steffer of the American Institute for Scientific Advancement.  "But the movement seems to be expanding beyond itself, creating hostility to other areas of biological research that haven't excited any particular public sentiment one way or the other in the past.  For example, public support for gene therapy has dropped thirty-six percent in the past two years alone."  [cont'd, p. 3]

It has been more than ten thousand years since the Chiliques Volcano last erupted.  It was considered entirely dormant until early 2002, when satellite imagery revealed the presence of hot magma just beneath the surface of the volcano's crater.  It has been considered an active volcano ever since then, and although the scientific community has mixed opinions about the scope and impact of an actual eruption, there is now little dispute that Chiliques will erupt within the next twenty years.

The eruption of this 18,957-foot stratovolcano could be explosive, and could come with very little warning.  Most scientists believe even an extremely explosive eruption would have minimal human impact due to the low population of the immediate region.
But Dr. Jorge Guerra of the First Scientific Church of Chiliques thinks otherwise.

"When this volcano erupts, it will be with such force as to rip a hole in the earth, out of which the angry spirits of our forefathers will rush with dark and murderous hearts.  The sky will be black with soot and the winds will howl with the cry of tortured spirits, and beasts will rise from the liquid rock and devour the wicked.  For Chiliques is the gates of Hell."

Dr. Guerra is currently in Santiago promoting his new book, "Preparing for the Apocalypse: How Not to Burn in Sulphurous Flame for Eternity"  (First Scientific Church Press).  At a recent bookstore speaking engagement, Dr. Guerra presented slides that he said offered "irrefutable proof" that Chiliques is indeed the portal to a fiery underworld, but which several hecklers in the audience quickly identified as still photographs from various movies.

Professor Juan Tindahl of the Santiago School of Vulcanology is skeptical.  "Dr. Guerra does indeed have a brilliant academic background, but ever since that accident with the lawnmower he's been [See GATES OF HELL, P. 3]
Carabineros in the Santa Rosa region are reporting an unusual spike in violent activity and have issued a warning to tourists in the area.

“We are advising tourists to avoid isolated rural areas in that northern region due to extensive violence.  The Peruvian and Bolivian border areas are especially unsafe for the time being,” said Carabinero spokesman Lt. Carlos Segovia.
The area is not heavily-traveled by tourists, but backpackers frequently do find themselves wandering out of the Andes into dangerous cartel-controlled territories.

“Some kind of cartel war seems to be heating up, and we don’t like to see tourists caught in the crossfire,” Lt. Segovia observed.  Ten to fifteen tourists and other foreigners die in the region each year, most often from exposure to the elements.  Violence typically only accounts for a small percentage of these deaths.
The small town of Santa Rosa is in mourning for the death of Jose Delgado, head of the successful Delgado & Son vineyard that was the financial backbone of the community.

“Jose was adored by everyone,” says one resident, a former vineyard employee.  “He was like a father to all of us.  He was a good, church-going man.  A very fine man.  It is a sad day for Santa Rosa.”

“Without Jose there is no vineyard,” sighs one long-time employee.  “And without the vineyard, there is no Santa Rosa.  It is like a great light has gone out.  Many of us will have to move.”  [See MOURNING, P. 6]

One year out from next year’s presidential election, incumbent U.S. President Tom Stewart enjoys strong support, healthy approval ratings, and seems likely to win re-election.  Many Stewart supporters, however, privately concede that the emergence of cloning as a central campaign issue may hurt their man.

The American scientific community appears divided on the question.  While no scientific organizations have come out explicitly in support of human cloning, organizations such as the American Scientific Association and the American Federation of Scientists have stated their opposition to any ban on human cloning.  The National Science Group and the American Scientific Society, on the other hand, have made no secret of their opposition to research in that area, and have already promised to use support for a ban on human cloning as their presidential litmus test.
According to Kim Clark, Communications Director of the Committee to Re-Elect Tom Stewart, [SEE CLONING, P. A5]
The battle for the White House has begun.

Lion Mutilates 42 Midgets in Cambodian Ring-Fight
Spectators cheered as the entire Cambodian Midget Fighting League squared off against an African lion late last week.
Tickets had been sold-out three weeks before the much-anticipated fight, which took place in the city of Kampong Chnang.
The fight had been slated after an angry fan assailed Yang Sihamoni, President of the CMFL, claiming that a single lion could defeat his entire league of 42 fighters.
The promoter took the challenge.  An African lion was shipped to centrally-located Kampong Chnang for the event, which took place Saturday in the city’s coliseum.
The Cambodian Government allowed the fight to take place under the condition that they receive a 50% commission on ticket sales, and that no cameras or mobile phones would be allowed in the arena.
The fight was called off after just 12 minutes.  Twenty-eight fighters were declared dead on the scene and the other 14 suffered severe to critical injuries.
Sihamoni took great pride in the league he helped create, as evidenced by a recent advertising campaign that boasted his midgets would "take on anything; man, beast, or machine."
Prior to the fight, Sihamoni declared that the numerical superiority of his fighters would allow them to "outwit and out-muscle the lion."
Lady Luck Gets a New Twang: Bayou Beauty Spreads the Chips
There's a mysterious new high-roller in town, and the pits are abuzz with speculation.  Who is she?  Where did she come from?  And where did she get all that money?

She's called the "Bayou Beauty" for plain enough reasons: her beauty is striking and her accent summons the bayous of the Mississippi delta.  She travels under the name of "Susan Smith" but, in the words of one pit boss who's seen her in action, "If her name's Sue Smith, then I'm George Washington."

Anonymous high-rollers are nothing new to Las Vegas, but the Bayou Beauty seems to have captured imaginations from one end of the strip to the other.  As one dealer put it, "I've seen millions of pretty women, thousands of rich women, and hundreds of pretty, rich high-rollers.  But I've never seen a pretty, rich high-roller that plays cards like the Bayou Beauty.  She's brilliant, she's a killer."  [MYSTERY WOMAN, p. 6]
Sheriff Calls Off Hunt for Escapees

The two death-row inmates who escaped incarceration during a spectacular attack on a prison transport from Nevada State Prison to Ely Conservation Camp remain at large, but local authorities are calling off their manhunt.

"We've exhausted pretty much all our leads," says Redstone County Sheriff John McConnico.  "We've got to face the facts: these guys are gone, and it's just a waste of resources to keep looking for them at this point.  I'm only speaking for local law enforcement, of course.  The feds are still going after these guys very aggressively."

Notorious mercenary Adam Marcus and the psychopathic "Mr. Little" are both convicted murderers and were on their way to be executed when their transport was attacked in the bloodiest episode of street warfare in Nevada history.  The episode triggered the largest manhunt ever conducted in the state.  The County Sheriff's decision to drop out of the effort may have been influenced by the increasingly bullying tactics of federal investigators.

Municipal authorities acknowledged yesterday that actions had been undertaken in accordance with the FBI's elevation of the national terror threat level from yellow to orange.  They would not disclose those actions specifically.

Aides in the mayor's press office responded to calls with a prepared text: "The city implements certain security measures in response to every change of the national threat level, whether or not Las Vegas is specifically identified by the federal authorities as being at-risk.  The mayor's office was notified of this elevation of the national terror threat prior to its being made public, and appropriate orders were given."

In addition to heightened military presence at local airports, residents and visitors may notice increased police patrols of congested areas and stricter security measures at the city's many public forums.  Most security measures, however, occur behind the scenes.
According to Dale Barry, Senior Security Consultant at Plato's Casino, security in Las Vegas "is already tighter than a [ORANGE ALERT, p. 3]
Global terrorism is a major threat to America
At first the neighbors thought a bomb had gone off.

"It was quiet like usual for a weeknight," Harry Cornack recalls, "and I was just having a little dinner in front of the TV, when all of a sudden BLAM!  The walls shook, the windows rattled, and I thought, 'Good lord, we're under attack!'"
Fortunately, or unfortunately, it wasn't a bomb or grenade that had gone off in a neighboring apartment.  It was a poodle.

Moira Cohen, Cornack's next-door neighbor for more than thirty years, had just given her toy poodle "Mrs. Dinky" a bath and was in a hurry to dry and groom her in time for Mrs. Dinky's showing at the Ugly Dog Show.
She apparently made the fateful decision to put the dog in the microwave after her blow-dryer shorted out.

"Most people aren't aware of certain explosive properties of the common toy poodle," Las Vegas Police forensic examiner Grant Cheek observes.  "Nature has, for reasons of her own, equipped toy poodles with certain super-charged hormonal secretions that have two unusual properties: they swell dramatically in heat, and they're extremely incendiary.  You may recall the military's infamous 'Poodle Bomb' experiments toward the end of the Cold War.  The Whigham Commission put a quick stop to that, but each and every toy poodle out there is still a potential bomb."
Mrs. Cohen was apparently as unaware as most Americans of the exploding poodle phenomenon, and she and her long-time companion Gertrude McCarthy paid for the oversight with their lives.
Mrs. Dinky received a posthumous Honorable Mention from the Ugly Dog Show.

The dust has finally settled and the organizers of the first Ugly Dog Show have announced it won't be the last.  The one-week extravaganza at the Las Vegas Convention Center brought in more than 150,000 tourists (each of whom spent an average of about $810 in the city) and 4000 of the world's ugliest dogs.

"We're pretty darn excited," says promoter Jeff Brookshire.  "We took a big risk and it paid off.  A lot of people asked me, they were like 'Jeff, you've finally lost your mind, who wants to pay money to look at a bunch of ugly dogs?'  But I never lost my faith.  I knew it was a winning idea and now the accounting speaks for itself.  Ugly dogs are here to stay, Las Vegas!"

The week-long Ugly Dog Show featured three days of ugly dog exhibition and ugly dog-themed entertainment, followed by a two-day ugly dog pageant that ultimately crowned a 16-year-old, one-eyed, three-legged mutt "Ugliest of Show." [UGLY, p. 5]
A spokesman for the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department announced yesterday that the LVMPD would be cracking down on raves and other underground parties in Las Vegas effective immediately.

“These parties violate zoning laws, entertainment laws, and are often hotbeds of illegal narcotics and prostitution,” said LVPD spokesman Matthew O’Neill at a press conference on the continuing investigation into the unfortunate “Heaven and Hell” tragedies.

“They represent a shadow industry of illegal activity that we intend to shut down beginning right now,” the red-faced spokesman proclaimed.  "I'm here to tell the scumbags behind the rave community: your days are numbered.  You can pack it up and get out of town, or we can hunt you down and lock you up.  Your call."

Mr. O'Neill appears to have his work cut out for him.  Rave organizers can earn hundred of thousands to millions of dollars for a single night of underground entertainment.  And demand for the illegal parties isn't likely to diminish, especially since the fact that they're illegal to begin with [RAVE CRACKDOWN, p. 3]

Local reaction to the first presidential debate appears to have been muted.  Telephone polls conducted yesterday suggested that neither candidate appeared to have gained or lost significant support as a result of the debate.

Frank Morgan continues to be the favored candidate of 51% of Nevada’s registered voters.  Las Vegas residents continue to favor President Stewart by a large margin, although the number of undecideds appears to be rising.

Both state parties claim the increase in undecided voters will benefit their candidates on Election Day, but unless President Stewart’s campaign gets some traction in rural areas, it’s extremely unlikely he’ll be able to carry the state in November.

When asked which candidate was strongest on national security, voters statewide favored Morgan by an almost 2-1 ratio.  When asked which candidate would do the most to protect their retirement, Stewart came out on top by the same 2-1 ratio.
Mike Daemon of Arlington was found dead yesterday, entangled in a safety net rigged just below the 8th floor of his apartment building.

The death was initially considered a homicide due to the gaping gunshot wound in the 24-year-old's chest.  Subsequent investigation revealed a suicide note, found on the building's roof, indicating that Mike Daemon intended to jump off the building to his death.  He was apparently shot and killed during the fall.

The murder weapon was later discovered to be an old Russian army pistol belonging to one of Daemon's two roommates, a pair of Russian exchange students.  Classmates of the Russians told police that they frequently pulled the gun out at parties and played Russian Roulette without any bullets.

The Russians told police that bullets for their gun are extremely difficult to come by, and that they've never owned or even attempted to purchase any.  They claim to have been astonished when the gun went off, and grateful it was aimed out the window and not at either of them.

Daemon's suicide note supports the Russians' story, as it suggests the despair that drove him to kill himself arose from his inability to kill the Russians, whose drinking and loud music had shattered his nerves.  He had apparently tried poisoning them in the past, and had loaded their gun in the hopes they would play Russian Roulette without realizing the pistol contained bullets.

The Russians claim he thrust the gun in their hands while they were drunk and dared them to play Russian Roulette.  They had tired of the game and no longer considered it amusing.  He reacted "kind of crazy," and shortly afterwards made his ill-fated trip to the roof.

Police believe that in loading the gun that killed him while he was in the middle of what otherwise would have been a failed suicide attempt, Mike Daemon was guilty of homicide in the shooting death of himself.

In a display of unity unseen since the immediate aftermath of 9/11, leaders of both houses of Congress gathered on the Capitol Steps late yesterday to express their solidarity in the face of a national tragedy.

Just as they did after 9/11, the legislators joined in a heart-felt rendition of "God Bless America," leading one long-time Capitol Hill observer to comment that it was a shame Congress couldn't sing any better than it could legislate.

Senators from both parties expressed their grief and outrage over the assassination of Vice-President Daniel Morris and vowed bipartisan commitment to bringing the perpetrators to justice.  Well-known political reporter Nadia Thorne quipped that "you couldn't take two steps in this town without tripping over someone's sorrow or bumping into their outrage."

The gathering threatened to descend into self-parody, however, when Senator Emily Jackson of Wyoming delivered a weepy homage to the late Vice-President.  Senator Jackson first rose to national prominence as a result of her strenuous and extremely vocal opposition to President Stewart's nomination of Mr. Morris earlier this year.  She famously referred to him at the time as "the most despicable human being that ever stained the earth with his rancid presence."  [BIPARTISAN SHOCK, p. A2]
For the first time since 9/11, America ground to a halt yesterday as the nation absorbed the terrible news that its vice-president had been assassinated.
Flags were lowered to half-mast, public events were cancelled, and Americans hurried home to be with their families.
"It was just so shocking," recalls Jennifer Grubman of Bethesda, "I was just, you know, totally shocked.  I'd say it was surprisingly shocking.  I'm still shocked."

Other Americans were saddened.  Jeremy Latham of Boston, who was in Washington on business, says, "Yesterday was a very sad day.  I just felt this overwhelming sorrow when I heard the news, this awful sadness overcame me.  These are very sad times, very sad."

Celia Chestwright of Apple Point, Ohio, heard the news from her own children, who'd come home early from school.  "I'd just been laying about, you know, reading a book, and in they come, hollering, 'Mommy, mommy, they killed the vice-president!'  And I was just so shocked, you know--but also sad.  I was shocked and saddened."
By Woody Stein, White House reporter
Vice-President Daniel Morris was assassinated at the White House yesterday by an assailant who was almost immediately shot to death by security personnel.
The identity of the assailant had not been made public at the time this article went to press.
The Vice-President was nominated by President Stewart earlier this year to replace the late Vice-President Spaulding Burke, who was killed in an automobile accident that continues to be investigated.

Congress confirmed the nomination of Mr. Morris with only minimal opposition. He had been identified beforehand as one of a handful of candidates to whose nomination the opposition Congress would consent.  He was not particularly popular with either political parties prior to his nomination, but was a savvy political operator with a reputation for moderate politics in all things but his opposition to human cloning, which was fierce and unrelenting.  Some opponents characterized it as obsessive.

The President will now have to nominate a replacement for his second Vice-President to have died in office.  Administration insiders say the president will not allow Congress to dictate his selection this time.
CIA Counter-Terrorism Experts “Stumped” by Recent Assassinations

In the wake of the current wave of high-profile assassinations around the world and sensational international headlines about a shadowy group of albino terrorists, CIA Counter-Terrorism experts find themselves unusually dependent on foreign governments—and no wiser for it.

“Frankly, everyone’s stumped,” says one veteran counter-terrorism operative, who spoke on condition of anonymity.  “Usually when you see this much action, on this broad a scale, you can’t help finding a smoking gun or two.  But we’ve got nothing.  Not only that--we can’t even dream up a unifying motive to figure out what they’re trying to accomplish.”

Another knowledgeable source frames the issue more bleakly.  “Any group that can do this much, this often, on this kind of scale, with this kind of reach, and remain this hidden not just to the CIA, but to virtually the entire worldwide intelligence community—well, it’s just not possible unless they’ve got at least a couple of governments in their pocket.  And that’s the really scary thing: which governments?”
U.S. State Department officials working in conjunction with various federal counter-terrorism units believe the usual suspects can be ruled out.

"Frankly," one such official told this reporter, "most of the so-called rogue governments just don't have this kind of reach.  They don't have the independent resources they'd need to coordinate something of this magnitude.  They'd have to be working with partners, and where there are partners there are leaks.  This has to have been organized by rogue elements within the community of developed western nations...  and that's what makes it so disturbing."
New Motto Bill Introduced in State Senate
It's no longer just a late-night talk show joke: Colorado is finally beginning to take the necessary political steps required to change its state motto.

The Latin motto "Nil sine Numine" is typically translated into English as "Nothing without Providence."  Comedians have emphasized for years that this would be an ideal motto for Rhode Island.  Some state lawmakers are beginning to tire of the joke.

"I guess in the old days Providence meant something like destiny or heaven or I don't know what," says 32-year-old State Senator Jackie Dawes of Glenwood Springs, "but these days when people hear 'Providence' they think, like, Rhode Island.  And I don't think that's what you want in a state motto.  Imagine if Rhode Island's motto was, like, 'Home of the Rocky Mountains' or something.  That wouldn't make much sense, would it?  I don't think so.  That's why I'm proud to be sponsoring the New Motto Bill."

State Senator Dawes is one of eight young State Senators behind the bill, which would create a process by which a new motto could be drafted, discussed, and ratified by voters.  The bill itself does not propose any alternatives.
The Senate is expected to vote on the bill tomorrow.
Mysterious Radiation Deaths Prompt Emergency Summits

The International Atomic Energy Agency has called an emergency summit to discuss the ramifications of the widely-publicized but still unexplained death of two Baghdad men from radiation poisoning, and to coordinate a global response to what may well be the first incident of "loose" weapons-grade plutonium.

The United Nations Security Council will also be meeting behind closed doors later today to discuss the situation, which one high-ranking officials has characterized as "the most significant nuclear threat since the Cuban Missile crisis."

In the United States, Stewart Administration officials have been issuing statements intended to soothe public fears.  "This isn't necessarily a doomsday scenario," Department of Defense spokesman Kyle Gordon said at a hastily-arranged press briefing last night.  "It's one thing for a terrorist organization to get their hands on some loose plutonium.  It's an entirely different story to try and get the technology to use that plutonium in a nuclear bomb."

[Denver] —Real football fans know that seasons are often won and lost long before the first mini-camps of spring.  In the era of free-agency gone amok, a franchise can make or break its chances with a single clause in a single player’s contract.  One bad trade, one un-renewed contract, and you can go from Super Bowl favorites to the divisional doghouse faster than a speeding bullet pass.

Orange and Blue fans should therefore take heart.  This may have been one of the best off-seasons in team history.  The already-formidable backfield has been strengthened with the re-signing of last year’s workhorses and a stellar draft.  The offensive line has been beefed up considerably and will certainly benefit from the addition of All-Pro offensive tackle Nathan Sedgefork.  Last year's suspect secondary has been completely overhauled.  And best of all, last week's acquittal of all-star wide-receiver Reggie "Psycho" Watson (on four of the five felony charges against him) suggests that he may be back in the line-up sooner than expected.
How to Replace an American Vice-President

In the wake of yesterday’s tragic death of Vice-President Spaulding Burke, the eyes of the world have slowly been turning to the 25th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.  In Section 2 of that amendment, which was ratified in 1967, it is stated that “Whenever there is a vacancy in the office of the Vice President, the President shall nominate a Vice President who shall take office upon confirmation by a majority vote of both Houses of Congress."

Most Washington insiders believe the President has already identified a short-list of possible nominees for the office, but House Majority Leader Bill Pyne, one of the president’s most outspoken critics, has already taken the offensive, stating in a press conference late last night that any nominees opposing a ban on human cloning will be denied confirmation by the opposition congress.

Most analysts believe the popular President Stewart has the political capital to withstand such a challenge, but some believe that, with the election cycle underway, he may be reluctant to spend it on a largely procedural fight that could detract from his campaign themes.

"A popular incumbent has all the advantages," says Ralph Duckett, professor of political science at Alexander Hamilton Business College.  "Getting into a political street-brawl this close to an election could only benefit his opponents.  He has nothing to gain and everything to lose.  Besides, in honoring any stipulations proposed by his opponents in Congress he'd be seen as reaching out, which can only help win the support of moderates."
A powerful explosion ripped through a residential neighborhood of the Parisien suburb of Bondy late last night, destroying three homes and killing five.
Though residents feared at first they'd been victimized by terrorism, police investigation into the incident suggests the culprit may have been much less formidable.

"There appears to have been a gas leak in the area," Lieutenant Jean Mercur of the Metropolitan Police reports, "so the only question we're left with is: what triggered the spark that set it off?  And I'm sad to say the answer seems to have been furry and adorable."

The lieutenant was referring to the more than twenty-four feline companions of Marie-Louise Kessel, aged 84, who died in the blast.  Police are speculating that it was a discharge of static electricity by one or more of the cats that sparked the powerful explosion.

"Anyone who's ever owned a long-haired cat knows they can generate static shocks when you touch them.  Based on the evidence we've been able to gather--which hasn't been pretty--it looks like Mrs. Kessel may have reached out to stroke one of her cats and ended up detonating the neighborhood."
The lieutenant stressed that many people have had long and rewarding relationships with long-haired cats without ever experiencing any fatal explosions.

[Brussels, Belgium] — Two shots rang out, the Brazilian Ambassador to Kenya fell to the ground clutching his chest, and a man with translucent skin and hair fled the scene.  Those are the facts agreed upon by everyone who witnessed Thursday’s assassination of Brazilian Ambassador Fernando Ribeiro at an open-air café in central Brussels.

Brazilian, Kenyan, and Belgian officials have appealed to the public for any information about the identity of the alleged “albino assassin,” who reportedly emerged from a taxi, fired two shots at the Ambassador’s chest, then fled the scene on foot.
Local law enforcement authorities are also still trying to determine the motive for the crime.  “Frankly we’re baffled,” says [Cont’d, p. 9]
US Veep Burke Dead in Car Wreck

Popular American Vice-President Spaulding Burke was killed in an automobile accident yesterday afternoon on a highway not far from the nation’s capital.   Washington D.C. Metropolitan Police report that the Vice-President’s limousine swerved out of control on Interstate 495, the so-called Washington “Beltway,” in College Point, Maryland, at approximately 5:40 p.m.  According to eyewitnesses, the limousine then spun wildly across the highway, flipped into oncoming traffic, and was struck by a southbound tractor-trailer.  The vice-president, his chief of staff, two aides, and the driver of the limo were declared dead on the scene by responding emergency medical technicians.

The vice-president leaves a wife, Tabitha Porter Burke, and two children, Andrew and Elizabeth, ages 8 and 6.  President Tom Stewart has declared today a national day of mourning for the late vice-president.  He is expected to nominate a replacement for the deceased vice-president by the end of the week.  No candidates had been named at the time this article went to press, but [Cont’d, p. 12]
U.S. Vice-President Burke was declared dead at the scene.

Humboldt County Economy Up in Smoke?

In a startling report that was supposed to remain confidential, County Controller Karen Lawes-Marston estimates that nearly one-fifth of all economic activity in Humboldt County appears to be drug-related.  The report, “Humboldt’s Hidden Economy,” was prepared at the request of the County Board of Supervisors and was not intended to be leaked to the press.

“This is all very speculative,” said Supervisor Harry Greene, referring to the report’s suggestion that 19.3% of the county’s economic activity was directly or indirectly related to the drug trade.  “We’ve all known there’s been a certain amount of illegal agricultural activity going on, but things seem to have kicked up a notch recently.  We’re not quite sure where that’s coming from, and we’re not sure the numbers are on target, which is why it’s so irresponsible to publish this story in the press.”

No other supervisor would comment on the story.  Ironically, the up tick in “shadow economy” drug money appears to have first surged at about the same time the world-renowned Pine Cone Rehabilitation Clinic first opened its doors to the world’s wealthiest addicts—most of them alcoholics, but also a small number of hard drug abusers.

Maybe their clients have been importing some back-up supplies?  Not likely, according to Pine Cone spokeswoman Anita Chevre.  "Once our clients step through those doors, the only way they get back out is when they're clean or when they're dead.  We are a one-hundred percent narcotics-free zone."
A bigger piece of the pie than expected.

After weeks of backroom negotiations and pressure politics at the highest levels of government, Congress has finally voted to approve President Tom Stewart’s nomination of Daniel Morris as interim Vice-President, filling the vacancy created weeks ago with the tragic traffic death of Spaulding Burke.

The opposition Congress refused even to hold votes on several of President Stewart’s previous nominations, standing by their original threat to withhold their approval from any nominee opposed to a ban on human cloning.  Mr. Morris, the darling of Wall Street during the biotech boom of the middle 1990s, has been agitating for such a ban since President Stewart took office, but has otherwise been a staunch supporter of the president and his policies.

Many Washington insiders have expressed surprise at the bullying tactics deployed by Congress to more or less “install,” as one source put it, the enigmatic Mr. Morris in the second-highest office of the land.

A federal transport van en route from San Francisco to Seattle was hijacked on Route 101 in Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park on Thursday.  A driver and two guards, federal employees whose names had not been released at the time this paper went to press, were bound and gagged while “at least three men” opened the van with explosives and relieved it of its only contents—exactly one kilo of uncut diamonds, with a street value of at least five million dollars.

The hijackers allegedly fled into the park after the hijacking.  Police have not been able to identify where or how they fled the area.  Foresnic examinations have yielded surprisingly little information.
“This appears to have been a well-planned, well-organized, carefully-executed job,” says State Trooper Mike Moran, one of several troopers who responded to [See DIAMONDS, page 3]

The Office of Independent Counsel Eliot Steadman announced this morning that the late vice-president’s long-time driver, Carl Wagner, was indeed a foreign national, having moved to the United States from his native Austria in 1999.  He never naturalized as an American citizen and some questions have arisen as to his Secret Service screening.

“It’s not illegal for a foreign national to be employed by a member of the Executive Branch,” Mr. Steadman explained in a memo distributed at the press briefing, “nor is there any question of any tax laws having been violated.  We would be remiss in our duties, however, if we neglected to explore the possibilities raised by the late Mr. Wagner’s foreign nationality.”

Austrian authorities confused matters further by reporting several hours later that Mr. Wagner was not an Austrian national, but had claimed refugee status in that country during the Balkan Wars of the 1990s.  The OIC had not responded to requests for a reaction to these statements [See DRIVER, page 5]

After many telephone calls from concerned residents, Assistant Commissioner George Tucker of the county Sheriff’s Department issued a press release on Thursday in which he said that reports of recent violence on Blueberry Court were exaggerated.

“The Sheriff’s Department would like to assure the residents of Cayuga Palms that, despite rumors to the contrary, no officers from our department or any other law enforcement agency were engaged in firefights in the Blueberry Court neighborhood at any time last week.  The Cayuga Palms community remains as safe as it always has been, and residents can rest assured that the county Sheriff’s Department intends to keep it that way.”

Phone calls made by this reporter to the FBI however went unanswered and the fact remains that numerous trustworthy residents in the Blueberry Court neighborhood, including this reporter, observed unusual and even frightening activity several days ago and nothing that Assistant Commissioner Tucker says can change that.

This reporter would like to see an independent investigation of the events which this reporter saw with her own two eyes.  This reporter would also like to hear from other residents who saw and heard some of the horrifying things that happened that day.

You may contact this reporter care of this paper, or visit her in her office in the community hall, right next to the women's locker room (the door still says "linen" but it's actually now the official office of this paper).
The Cayuga Palms Board of Directors held their quarterly meeting last night and heard arguments on the proposed new controversial barbecue and grill code for Cayuga Palms properties.

Supporters of the code say that certain residents have taken advantage of the lack of regulations by building what one resident called “giant industrial gas grills” in their backyards.  Some of these big grills are ten to twelve-feet high.  Angry residents claim the smoke they produce when they’re being used might violate certain California environmental laws although none of those addressing the board cited any particular regulation.  Chuck Hanson of Briar Court says one of his neighbors barbecued “a whole cow” recently and this was very upsetting to him and his wife who are both vegetarians although they do sometimes eat fish.

Those who oppose the code say they have the right to build or install anything they want in their backyard, and “roast as many cows as we want,” as long as it doesn’t violate existing laws.  They argued it was unfair to change laws after they’d already spent their money on these grills.

The Board is expected to give a decision early next month.  Residents who want to register their own particular comments about the issue but couldn't make time to attend the meeting can submit their comments in writing to the administrative offices.

At the meeting the board voted that community owners have to be reminded that all guests have to use parking vouchers, which they haven’t been.  A proposal to increase the community's communications budget, which would have really helped this paper, was also shot down by the unsympathetic board.  But mainly most of the controversy was really about the grill code and the debate was very heated.  (Hee hee.)

Margaret Phillips of Blossom Lane has retained the law firm of Liddy Gate & Winn to support her claim against the Cayuga Palms Community Planning board for negligence in playground planning.  She claims the negligent planning led to serious injuries to her daughter Clara.
"It's not a playground," Mrs. Phillips says, "it's a deathtrap.  This lawsuit isn't about the money.  It's about protecting the other children."

She says her daughter Clara allegedly lost her balance on top of the jungle gym because she was trying to light a cigarette without spilling her beer.  She lost her balance and fell, breaking her arm and dislocating her shoulder.  Mrs. Phillips says the playground should have had signs prohibiting the use of tobacco and alcohol products, and that her 12-year-old daughter wouldn't have been injured if such signange was there.  The community has offered $412.58, which is the cost of the medical bills, and promised to post new signs.  Mrs. Phillips's lawyers rejected the offer and want $1.8 million in damages.

For the first time in its history, the FBI most-wanted list features an albino at the top of the charts.  The fugitive in question is believed to be responsible for a number of recent assassinations across the world.  The unidentified albino has been cited in so many cases that many law enforcement agencies believe he’s a mere urban legend.  Others suspect a group of albinos may be working together and that witnesses have noticed only their albinism—thus misleading the FBI and Interpol to conclude erroneously that they're seeking a single operative.  Conspiracy theories abound.  The Albino Anti-Defamation League (AADL) isn’t amused.

“Albinos are no different from anyone else,” says AADL spokesman Marvin LeBlanc.  “You can’t say anything meaningful about ‘all albinos’ any more than you can about ‘all redheads’ or ‘everyone with freckles.’  The man being sought by the FBI may well be the murderous criminal their bulletins suggest him to be, but the fact that he’s an albino is completely beside the point.”
Albinism is a rare genetic condition.

[IPA]  Macklin for Veep: Although the administration continues to insist publicly that President Stewart will not be dumping interim Vice-President Daniel Morris from the ticket during this summer’s convention, one high-ranking White House insider says Interior Secretary Jimmy Macklin leads the short list of prospective Vice-Presidential replacements.  Neither the President nor Secretary Macklin have commented on the story.

[IPA]  Lone Albino Theory Goes Down (Down Under):  In the wake of last Saturday’s assassination of Ukrainian General Viktor Moroz in Kiev, at which eyewitnesses and video surveillance both confirmed the presence of a suspicious albino on the tarmac, and the assassination of Australia’s National Science Advisor in Melbourne just 14 hours later, law enforcement officials around the world have been compelled to concede that the so-called “Albino Assassin” may indeed be more than one person.  The idea of multiple albinos working together in an international criminal enterprise had previously been rejected as an “urban legend” or “conspiracy theory” by most law enforcement agencies around the world.

[NII]  UN Evacuated: The United Nations building in Manhattan was evacuated yesterday after agency officials and New York Police received "specific and credible" threats from anonymous telephone callers.  The evacuation was orderly and no damage or injuries were reported.  Police now believe the call to have been a hoax.  The evacuation resulted in the general assembly's vote on a human cloning ban being postponed yet again.
by Stephan St. Martin, Globe columnist
According to police reports and Department of Health statistics, fewer people died of alcohol-related deaths at this year’s Mardi Gras celebrations than in any of the last twenty-seven years.

Festival organizers say this year’s “Party More, Drink Less” campaign, in which celebrity spokespeople, professional athletes, and supermodels urged the public to drink in moderation, was responsible for the improvement.

According to Steve Walker, Executive Director of Citizens for Sobriety, lower mortality rates weren’t the only positive outcome of the campaign.  “We also had less drunk-and-disorderly arrests than any season in the past three decades.  There were even fewer arrests for public lewdness and indecent exposure.”  Walker believes most celebrants have lost touch with the religious significance of Mardi Gras.  "I've got nothing against a glass or two of wine to relax, or even a little more to celebrate, and we ought to celebrate Mardi Gras enthusiastically, but you see these inexperienced kids drinking just gallons of booze, and you know nothing good's going to come of it."

Some veteran Mardi Gras participants, however, seemed unenthusiastic about the improved statistics.  “Public lewdness shouldn’t even be a crime,” said one 82-year-old New Orleans native.  “I probably can’t even tell you some of the things I saw when I was a boy or they’d come and arrest me, too.  These puritans ought to go back where they came from.  Lousy spoil-sports.  Back in my day we'd have whipped their sanctimonious butts and given 'em corn-liquor enemas...”

"That's just the kind of attitude we've got to overcome," says Walker.  "The idea that you're being a quote-unquote 'spoil-sport' because you want to help people have a good time without getting sick or in trouble or hurting themselves... it's just sad."

When WNOX-TV announced last Friday that this week would see the debut of a new "Vampire Watch" segment on their "Channel 8 News at 10," we assumed the announcement was being made with the same tongue-in-cheek attitude that's made WNOX such a quirky independent local station.

Alas, it seems management wasn't joking.  We've watched each installment of the "Vampire Watch" segment with increasing dismay.  It isn't just the tasteless costuming of hostess Eva Succubus, or the childish use of gimmicks and special effects, but the sheer stupidity of the segment.

Here, for example, is the complete text of last night's broadcast: "Good evening, N'Awlins, this is Eva Succubus with your WNOX Channel 8 Vampire Watch.  Our Vampire Radar has picked up two Category 3 vampires in the Garden District.  You'll want to load up on garlic if you're passing through that neighborhood tonight...  be sure to check our website for lots of great garlic recipes and [See BAD TASTE, p. A29]
Public support for cloning is rising in Louisiana in the wake of recent acts of violence directed toward its defenders.

“This violence is perceived, rightly or wrongly, as being organized or at least perpetrated by anti-cloning zealots,” explains Bayou Polling Corporation (BPC) spokesperson Jennifer Graham.  “That seems to be turning a lot of undecideds into active cloning supporters.”

According to the most recent BPC numbers, support for cloning among registered voters in New Orleans has increased from 42 to 48% in the last seven days.  Statewide, support went from 39 to 44%.  Opposition to cloning locally and statewide remains steady at 48 and 45%, respectively.

"This is obviously the hot-button issue of the day," Graham observed, "and we're beginning to see indications that it's actually becoming a more influential factor on how favorably or unfavorably political candidates are perceived by likely voters.  It's also becoming a more reliable predictor than older issues like abortion, gun control, and hurricane reconstruction."

School Board Tells Kids BYO Ammo

The Hunter County School Board voted on Wednesday that high school students would have to start supplying their own ammo for marksmanship class which is an elective that is not reimbursed by the state or federal funds.

“Basically we got to choose between kids buying their own ammo or shutting the class down completely,” said Hank Thornton, chairman of the School Board.  “We know this ain’t a popular decision but for the past three years we been spending more money on marksmanship class than some educational subjects and we just can’t keep that up, especially when marksmanship is just an elective anyway.”
Angry parents at the meeting said they would organize themselves to get the school board members replaced by “people who know crap from crapola.”
Hank Thornton says he "don’t mind none since the job don’t pay so good and [he’s] tired of putting up with it all and been thinking about retiring for a good while anyhow."

"Hank Thornton's a good man," Jeb Clayfoot acknowledged, "but there's a little thing in this here country's constitution called the second amendment, and ain't nobody, not even Hank Thornton, gonna take away my boy's God-given, constitutionally-protected right to learn how to defend him self. I didn't pay for no ammo, my daddy didn't pay for no ammo, my granddaddy didn't pay for no ammo, and my boy sure as hell ain't gonna pay for no ammo so long as this here school board's runnin' off money I made off the sweat a my brow."

Now that the conventions are over, President Stewart and Frank Morgan can get down to some serious campaigning.  The Chicago and Houston conventions didn’t offer no surprises, and we should probably all be greatful they held them at the same time for once so we didn’t have to suffer through twice as long.

This newspaper is ready to go on the record already in support of Frank Morgan.  We urge our readers to vote for him.  A lot of delta residents have told us they don’t see the big deal about cloning, about why it’s such a big campaign issue.  Well, folks, look at it this way: cloning’s just copying people, and there’s such a hell a lot of people out there ain’t none of us want copied.

Frank Morgan has promised to ban cloning forever and to work with the U.N. and E.U. and all them gasbags about getting a worldwide ban.  President Stewart used to say he supported cloning, now he says he’d just leave it up to the scientific community.  Either way, he’s just not taking it serious enough.
The Delta Weekly thinks we deserve a president that takes cloning seriously.  That’s why we think Frank Morgan is the man for the job.

Every four years we like to find what kinds of things local residents are thinking about when they cast their votes for president.  Two weeks ago we invited readers to call or write us their opinions, and members of the Delta editorial board have been talking it up with locals.

Editors recently set themselves down at Kay’s Katfish Korner to get the pulse of the community over a few frostys. Surprise, surprise, almost everyone we talked to said they were going to vote against President Stewart this fall. The reasons were different from one person to another, but almost everyone agreed President Stewart was just no good on national security.  Lots of people also said they figured he was pretty out of touch with regular folk and came off as a typical yankee elitist.  As one local put it, "I don't like havin' a president that looks and acts like he ain't never hooked his own bait."

We also asked about the Olympics: were folks watching?  What events?  Was there anything missing?  We stirred up a heck of a hornet's nest with those questions.  Seems most local folk gave up [see page 3]
Former CIA Director Surprises Ole Miss Alumni

Ole Miss alumnis attending a University of Mississippi fundraising last Thursday night in Oxford was just amazed when fellow alumni and former CIA Director Leland “Jack” Alexander (’53) made a unscheduled appearance to support the school.  Mr. Alexander talked about growing threats to national security and the need for improvements in American intelligence operations.  He didn’t mince words about the current Stewart administration’s failures in these areas.

“We know the terrorists are out there,” he said, “and we know there’s rogue governments with terrifying arsenals at their disposal."  The idea of some Anti-American terrorist getting his hands on nuclear, biological, chemical, or cloning technology from one of these governments is unthinkable, but Mr. Alexander said the Stewart administration hasn't done jack diddley squat to prevent it.

He said the administration’s failure to treat cloning as a weapon technology was one of its worst and most dangerous of all its failings.  He asked his audience to imagine an army of super-warriors cloned from Olympic athletes, or a rogue government with a whole university full of clone Einsteins, and so on.  He said America had a special moral responsibility in the world and if we didn't make human cloning illegal here, why then most likely nobody would anywhere.

"This administration ain't got the moral sensibility God gave a junebug," Mr. Alexander said to great applause.  The audience was mostly very receptive to his remarks.  Some protestors did start chanting at one point, but they got shut up pretty quick.

Mr. Alexander also told alumnis about his favorite local drinking and fishing spots from back when he was a student and also a few reminiscences of his own college days.  One time he caught a forty-eight pound catfish.
Widowed at the Altar: Local Woman Faces Hardship, Challenges

Margeaux LeBlanc was the kind of gal that had it all.  Smart, pretty, and the daughter of one of the wealthiest men in the region, she was engaged to a handsome fellow with a promising future of his own.  That all changed on Saturday when what should of been the happiest day of her whole life turned into a terrible nightmare.  By the end of the day, her daddy was dead and her groom was too.
She wouldn’t even have been married if it wasn’t for the fact what that her and her beau got hitched in secret by the county clerk before the actual wedding ceremony itself.

The grieving widow hasn’t hardly been seen since then.  Rumor has it she’s so struck with grief that she’s selling all her daddy’s and husband’s holdings and getting out of the area completely, though no one seems to know where a girl like her might go.
Hunter County School Board Chairman Hank Thornton turned in his resignation on Tuesday saying that he’d had enough and looked forward to more time fishing with his grandchildren and such.

Things have been pretty hot for the School Board lately ever since the Board voted to make students buy their own ammunition for marksmanship class.  Parents say ammo costs money and not all families can afford the expense of providing ammo for their kid’s training two or three times a week especially when so many local residents got three or four kids in school at once.

Jonas “Moose” Miller, father of three boys in high school, was so angry at the last meeting he had to be taken out by police after he started firing shots in the ceiling and didn’t stop until Officer George Dayton snuck up and konked him upside the head with his nightstick.

Miller is still in County Hospital but says he’s going to run for Thornton’s empty seat on a platform of free ammo.  Police say they won’t press charges but Miller will have to pay to fix the ceiling in the high school gym where the meeting was held, which he shot all to hell.
The Hunter County School Board has called a special election to replace retired Chairman Hank Thornton and voters can vote at the high school gym next Tuesday.

Candidates include two members of the current board and Jonas “Moose” Miller, whose become a kind of celebrity ever since he shot hell out of the gym ceiling during the last official meeting of the school board and had to be drug off by police although he wasn’t formally arrested and had to spend two days in County Hospital on account of Officer Dayton konking his head.

Moose Miller says he would keep our kid’s ammo free by saving money by cancelling other expenses such as new history textbooks.  “History ain’t changed since I was a boy,” Moose says, “so I don’t see why we got to keep buying new history books.”

His main rival, Lee Gaitlin of Marlsberg, is already a member of the school board but believes he should be its next chairman.  "I could kick Moose's behind in high school, I can sure as hell kick it now.  He ain't fit to fill Hank Thornton's shoes.  Hell, he ain't fit to polish 'em."
Locals Make Fortune Selling Hitler Memorabilia Online

There’s an old pair of socks for sale on a popular online auction site, and when this paper went to press the high bid was four hundred dollars.  You might think that’s a lot of money for an old pair of socks and you’d be right.  Thing is, they used to belong to Adolf Hitler, and Hitler memorabilia is big business.

The seller is anonymous, just a PO box over in Red Bluff, but you can find a whole mess of Hitler stuff for sale online coming out of the delta region.  From socks to cuff-links, from shoehorns to hair brushes, if Hitler touched it, someone wants to buy it.  And where there’s buyers, there’s sellers.

Local law enforcement officials say there isn’t anything illegal about the trade in Hitler memorabilia, but that buyers should be real cautious because it’s hard to authenticate these kinds of things.

"I could take any old pair of socks I got lyin' round the house and say what they used to belong to Robert E. Lee, Andy Jackson, or the King of frickin' Siam," explains officer Jedediah Jefferson of the Red Bluff police.  "And though it's technically fraud if I try to sell 'em as such, y'all gonna have to prove they ain't what I says they are to make your case.  And that ain't as easy as it sounds."

That much said, Jefferson reckons most of this Hitler stuff is genuine.  "The kind of folks what go collectin' Hitler memoribilia ain't the kind of folks y'all wanna disappoint," he says.  "They ain't got what you'd call a real forgivin' disposition."

This reporter contacted some of the sellers, but none of them was willing to meet with me or even identify themselves, although one guy selling Hitler cuff-links did inform me that he expected at least a hundred thousand dollars for them.  Each!  Besides socks and cuff-links, recent local listings included Hitler's hairbrush, a Hitler beer stein, and, nasty as it sounds, a pair of Hitler's undergarments.  Total price tag if you wanted all of them?  More than one million dollars.

"We value our employees highly. This will not be forgotten. We need to hire more people.", says Head of Casino Security, Leo Lummerkrog.
"We're paid to watch at night. Not to get killed. We hope the police will find the killer.", comments nightwatch chief, Bent Bendtsen.
Secretary to the head of security of the president says; "This case now has highest priority. Every available resource is being used to find the killer!"
Chief of the Opera Security comments, "This is a tragedy. We all hope the person who did this will die."
Security manager, Martin Pollas, comments "This is the worst day in my life. Those guys were not only colleagues, they were my friends."
FBI chief comments: "The killer will be found. The bureau can find anyone, and this time we will."
Police Chief Wiggum comments; "This is a very serious crime, we will do everything in our power to find the killer and have him put in the chair."

Joseph Clarence was one of the region's most colorful personalities in the 80s and 90s, and no southland social event was complete without his attendance.  Handsome, charming, witty and successful, he radiated success.

Following the devastating accident that closed his park, bled his fortune and eventually even cost him his marriage, the Swing King deteriorated into a lonely and reclusive soul, living a hermit's existence in the shadows of his park.

Rise and fall stories are woven into the very fabric of our national character, but something about the Swing King's rise seemed more extraordinary than most...  and something about his fall more tragic.
It shouldn't have been surprising to anyone that someone whose life had all the soaring highs of the roller coasters it was built on should also have all their thundering lows.

And the lows, from what little of his recent life has been made publicly available, were indeed low.  Police believe he may actually have been reduced to renting parts of the park to gangs and drug dealers.
Hollywood was not immune to the allure of the Swing King story.  It's already been reported that Quantum Shoe Pictures has been negotiating with his widow for the rights to his story.

Mohammad bin Faisal Al-Khalifa was fifty-four years old and the CEO of Arabian Pharmaceutical Exports, Inc (APEX), whose anti-depressant drug Encephamol is expected to receive FDA approval later this year.
The Sheik was one of the Saudi kingdom's many billionaires and had an international reputation as something of a playboy, with a special fondness for blackjack, craps, and poker.
In a single session at a high-rolling Las Vegas craps table in 2003, the Sheik lost more than four million dollars in forty-five minutes without losing his smile.

He was as decadent as he was extravagant.  Tabloids gleefully reported that at his most recent birthday, held on his 184-foot private yacht, he invited guests to lick beluga caviar off the otherwise naked bodies of dozens of beautiful young women.

He made international headlines in 2002 when the press published photographs of one of his orgies: it was not the sheer pornographic vulgarity of the photos that generated interest so much as the cast of characters.
In recent years the Sheik had rarely been seen in public without being accompanied by Tariq Abdul Lateef, the fashion-conscious scientist believed to be the brains behind APEX's success.

The extent of Mr. Martinez' work with the CIA is unknown, for obvious reasons.  Local authorities were unwilling to speculate as to whether or not his intelligence background had anything to do with his death.
"Not everyone who works for the CIA ends up dead at a Las Vegas party," quipped one investigator who didn't seem amused by reporters' persistent questions about Martinez' background.
Mr. Martinez had been living in Key West for the past few years.  Little is known about his activities there, but he does seem to have done an unusual amount of traveling.
According to his Key West neighbors, he was a quiet but friendly man who kept to himself.  None of the neighbors interviewed by this paper knew anything about his CIA background.

The Central Intelligence Agency would not even confirm that Mr. Martinez had ever worked for them.  Nor would agency representatives comment on the possible implications of his apparently violent death.
Mr. Martinez studied anthropology and psychology as an undergraduate, and held a Master's Degree in Asian history.  He was fluent in over a dozen languages.

Prior to his nomination to the vice-presidency earlier this year, Daniel Morris was an intensely--some would say obsessively--private person.  Aides say he never did come to terms with the increased exposure of his new role.

"His philosophy was that if you had a job to do, you ought to be able to just do it.  He could appreciate the important role of the press as a bulwark against abuse of privilege by those in power, but he didn't see how that applied to him."
"I think the press was always a little wary of him, and that made him wary of the press.  He wasn't exactly secretive, but he was pretty private.  The Washington press corps doesn't like that."
In recent weeks the press had been playing up reported differences between the late vice-president and the first lady, but aides were always quick to dismiss such gossip.

"They weren't what you'd call best friends," one White House aide said on condition of anonymity, "but they got along just fine.  All this stuff you hear about temper tantrums and name-calling and all that...  it's just silly."
The first lady's spokeswoman insists that she and the vice-president were on excellent terms: "She had nothing but respect for the late vice-president, and that respect was reciprocated."
Fernando Xalvador Delgado was one of Chile's most respected vintners, with an international reputation for excellence.  His wines have won competitions around the world.
He was also an accomplished cellist.  Though he seldom performed in public, guests at his private parties were frequently entertained by his cello playing.  He composed many pieces himself.
One such composition, the oddly-named "Ode to a Scream", was actually performed by the National Symphony Orchestra at a summer concert in 1994 and received favorable reviews from critics.
The retired Colonel was also a collector of rare butterflies, describing his interest as a natural extension of his fascination with "all that is beautiful, delicate, gentle, and quiet."

"They call the study of butterflies lepidopterology," the colonel once joked in an interview, "and that's enough to scare anyone away from butterflies for good.  One must be careful what one calls things."

The thousands of men and women whose own lives were enriched by this generous, humble, and deeply spiritual colonel feel his loss acutely.  There is a sense in this small community that something vital has been lost.
Chad Jr. had become the black sheep of the family in recent years, and local tabloids frequently ran unflattering photographs of the young man engaged in morally dubious behavior.

He was rapidly becoming a political liability for his father, whose sights have clearly been set on the White House for some time.  Friends say it was actually admiration for his father that drove the young man to such excess.

"He wasn't like his old man and he knew it," says one friend.  "He felt like a total disappointment whatever he did.  So he just kind of gave up on things, you know, and I guess it was pretty inevitable he'd die young."

Several Denver prostitutes have told the tabloids they were physically abused by Bingham.  Unsubstantiated rumors of his involvement in the death of a popular stripper continue to circulate.  His father dismisses it all as slander.

"The sad truth," the senator observed in a local television interview last month, "is that when you run for high elected office, your whole family becomes fair game for these sleazeball journalists.  It's disgusting."

"The whole family's pretty shaken up," says one aide to the Senator.  "There aren't going to be any official statements or anything.  The family just needs to get through this thing and hopes the press will let them grieve their loss privately."
Alvaro D'Alvade's perfectionism was legendary in the opera world, where it paid off in terms of the consistently astonishing technical brilliance of his performances.  But it had its dark side.

Rumors of an explosive temper and an eccentric sexual appetite dogged him throughout his otherwise illustrious career.  Some leading ladies of the opera refused to perform with him.  Some operas black-listed him.

In 1997, a Bulgarian court attempted to prosecute him for the statutory rape of a thirteen-year-old girl.  The case was ultimately dropped when the girl first declined to testify then simply disappeared.
Prosecutors even tried to pin the girl's disappearance on D'Alvade, but her body was eventually discovered in a hollow at the bottom of a steep ravine and her death was ruled a suicide.
The episode hurt D'Alvade professionally.  Although he was never convicted of a crime, his reputation had been soiled enough to reduce international demand for his performances.

Critics have called him "the greatest Cavaradossi in the history of opera" and, whatever his personal failings, his performance in this production of Puccini's "Tosca" was eagerly anticipated by opera enthusiasts.
The Pine Cone Rehabilitation Clinic enjoys a stellar reputation as the most successful, luxurious, and discreet rehabilitation clinic in North America.  Its client list is a closely guarded secret.

Despite the secrecy, it's well-known that dozens if not hundreds of movers and shakers from politics and entertainment have cleaned up their acts at Pine Cone. Some celebrities have openly acknowledged that the program saved their lives.
One Hollywood publicist has even been said to send even his "clean" clients to the clinic to boost their careers, so potent is the high-gloss mystique of this facility.

The clinic's controversial policy of discharging only "the clean and the dead" has brought it under legal scrutiny, but investigations have never revealed anything but an intensely dedicated staff working with state-of-the-art methods.

At the time of admission, all clients are required to sign a waiver acknowledging that they will not leave the clinic until they are "clean" or dead.  A clinic spokesman says this scares away those who aren't really committed to keeping clean.

Critics of the clinic call it a cheap publicity stunt.  "I could open a restaurant and say no one ever leaves until they're fed or dead," says one consulting physician from a less glamorous clinic.  "That wouldn't tell you anything about my food."
Vinnie Sinistra, age 43, an expatriated Cuban, was "exported" by Castro like so many other criminals in the late 80's. Sinistra had been involved in organised crime all his life.

He quickly teamed up with Sammy Falconetti and Bobby Mazur to form one of Miami's most notorious drug smuggling trios. They are believed to have smuggled several tons of cocaine by boat from the Bahamas during the 90's.

Sinistra was wanted by the FBI for the murder of Luiz Zukowski, a state witness against the drug trio. Sinistra was placed under the federal witness protection program when he turned himself in after a month-long nationwide manhunt.
Almost 20.000 people in the US have entered the federal witness protection programme since its inception in the 1970's.  Sinistra's victim, Luiz Zukowski, was in the program at the time of his death.
Authorities insist that these two cases are exceptions to the rule: federally protected witnesses ordinarily live out their days in peace.  Very few die violent deaths.
But, according to one federal employee who insisted on anonymity, "it ain't like it breaks your heart when one a these scumbags goes down."

Raymond Kulinsky qualified for the U.S. winter Olympic team as a biathlon athlete in 1992.  Shortly after qualifying, he injured his knee while biking and was unable to recuperate in time for the games.
He then reportedly entered a deep depression that eventually led to his embarking upon a life of crime.  Kulinsky has been one of the FBI's 100 most-wanted criminals since 1996.

An FBI field office spokesperson identified Kulinsky as one of the ten most-wanted assassins in North America.  He's believed to have been responsible for nearly two-dozen assassinations in the last eight years.
"There's no question the world is a better place without Raymond Kulinsky in it," says one FBI official familiar with the case.  "He was a dangerous, deadly, hateful man."
Officials would not discuss the particulars of his career, the details of their investigation, or whether they've made any progress in identifying the person or persons behind Kulinsky.

"Assassins don't pick their own targets," another law enforcement official familiar with the investigation observed.  "So when we bag one of these dogs, our first question is always: who's got the leash?"

Captain Skip Muldoon was a flamboyant character familiar to everyone in the delta region.  He was a man of extravagant tastes and outspoken opinions.  He was also rumored to be the head of a local drug syndicate.
He was as secretive as he was fastidious.  His passion for cleanliness and order on his ship was second only to his passion for fried food and baked goods.

Captain Muldoon had been running tourist and excursion cruises up and down the Mississippi for nearly twenty years.  The Riverboat Pilots Association voted him Riverboat Captain of the Year for three consecutive years in the 90s.
Law enforcement officials were not as pleased with Captain Muldoon as the RPA, however.  Federal and state officials launched three investigations into the captain's operations between 1995 and 2003.
According to local police, however, Captain Muldoon was nothing more than he appeared to be: a flamboyant and meticulous riverboat captain with a soft spot for fatty foods--and lean young men.
Captain Muldoon was also an avid marksman, and enjoyed showing off his accuracy by taking shots at local wildlife while his boat was underway.  This habit did little to endear him to authorities.

John "Pappy" LeBlanc was a fixture in the delta region.  A successful businessman who never lost touch with his roots, Pappy had a winning blend of old-school charm, down-home common sense, and ruthless business savvy.
Most friends and associates acknowledge that Pappy's cognitive faculties had been breaking down over the last few years, but all of them stressed he was still not a man to be underestimated.

"Ol' Pappy talked a lot of crap about UFOs and government plots and secret cloning labs and I don't know what all," says long-time friend Henrick Slackjaw, "but he was still one shrewd son-of-a-gun, if you know what I mean."
Despite his reputation, the extent of his business interests and the scope of his fortune, as revealed by the usual post-mortem legal inquiries, have astonished even many of those who knew him best.

"We all knew Pappy was doing all right," recalls one business associate, "but I don't think anyone had any idea just how all right that was.  I reckon you coulda knocked his little girl over with a feather when she found out."

"What's a sweet little thang like that gonna do with all them hundreds of millions of dollars?  Just gonna put a whole lotta stress on that pretty little head of hers.  And her without a husband now.  It just ain't right."

Police express high confidence in the accuracy of the depiction of their composite sketch. The sketch has several similarities with the legendary Agent 47, but evidence collected at the crime scene suggests he is a copycat.

With the help of hundreds of eye witnesses, the police have finally been able to develop an accurate sketch of the killer. Black suit, white shirt, red tie and bald and white as the moon is what characterizes this professional hitman. He also doesn’t speak much.
